title: A touching farewell to The Archers' Joe Grundy shows the power of being human on radio
text:
Does it matter if things are real on the radio? Doing an impression of someone for laughs, a la Dead Ringers, is one thing. Faking sincerity is so much harder.

That’s the reason political interviews are often so much more illuminating on the radio than they are on TV. Without being able to see an MP’s face, for instance, we concentrate so much harder on the way they say things. Shiftiness is detectable in even the slightest change of vocal timbre, and nobody has yet invented makeup or fancy suits that work via sound. On the radio, everyone’s naked. Or are they? Could we already have been deceived?

That’s partly what the enjoyably fizzy, futuristic documentary Make Me a Programme (Radio 4, Monday)...
description: Does it matter if things are real on the radio?
